args:
On Mitsuhide's invitation, Ieyasu and Marishiten
visit a fishing village home to legends of buried
treasure. Intrigued by tales of lost Hinomotoan
gold, Ieyasu begins his search at the bottom of
a suspicious well.

South Grastaea - Fellista Beach

Ieyasu, leader of the Boar Clan, has come to
survey the region in an effort to develop new
anti-flooding measures.
Back from yet another foray across the\nwaves on one of those ancient vehicles?
It's on loan from the local lifeguard.\nNo reason not to put it to full use\nbefore we return to Hinomoto.
It's my hope that this experience will\ninform the design of a new high-speed\nship someday.
Ah, yes. You're only splashing around in\nthe surf for science and the good of all\nmankind. Oh, right—a letter came for you.
It's from Mitsuhide. If I recall, she\nwas also on vacation in the south.
That she's found something interesting\nwhere she's staying: a fishing town called\nAquagi. She asks if we want to join her.
This is the place, huh? No offense to the\nlocals, but I'm guessing they've seen better\ndays here.
Do I spy who I think I do?! Everyone, out!\nOut of your homes and into the street!
Don't let them slip away! Get in there and\nshow them our special brand of hospitality!
Oho. If it's a fight they want, I'm all too\nhappy to oblige. Kid gloves are off—
Welcome to Aquagi, honored guests! Here,\nenjoy a cool swig of our village specialty!
If you need a place to stay the night, you'll\nfind no finer than our inn. It's seen its\nshare of years, but breakfast is included!
And here's our famous flavorless shaved\nice. It's not that we're too cheap to add\nthe syrup; it's supposed to be like this!
Geniality is the key to repeat visitors. I\nwant to see every one of you dig deep and\nfind a service industry BEAST inside of you!

You know, I'm so used to two-bit thugs
spouting ＂hospitality＂ metaphors that I
almost forgot the word could be used
sincerely. Talk about intense, though.
The fishing industry ain't what it used to\nbe, I'm afraid. We're diversifying our\ntown's portfolio into the tourism business.
Yeah? How's that going for you? Not well,\nI'm guessing, since we're the only tourists\nhere.
Don't be rude, Marishiten. Sir, has a lady\nby the name of Mitsuhide come through\nthese parts of late?
Oh, yes, she's staying at our inn.\nAre you two from Hinomoto as well?
My word! For so many Hinomotoan guests\nto gather here at once...it must be destiny!
Does your village bear some\nconnection to our homeland?
Oh, indeed! Indeed it does!\nAfter all, this land is where...
Heh heh heh... It's a tale passed down\nfor generations here in Aquagi.
Long, long ago, a samurai of Hinomoto washed\nup on our shores clutching a wooden chest.\nOur ancestors here nursed him back to health.

In thanks, the samurai toiled in our fields
and beat back the fiends that threatened us.
In time, he put down roots and became one of
us. But never once did he reveal the contents
of the chest he'd arrived with.

One year, a plague struck the village. The
samurai said that he would dig a well to help
heal the sick, and so he set out past the
village's edge. A child fond of the samurai
followed him, and saw something remarkable.

The samurai's chest lay open, its contents solid
gold. He buried it beneath the earth, piece by
piece. Some time later, the samurai vanished
from the village.
Digging a well was merely a pretense\nto keep his gold a secret. It is said his\nwealth slumbers there to this day...
Thus goes the legend of the great buried\ntreasure of Hinomoto, long told in Aquagi.
If we knew that, we'd be there with spades\nin hand right now! Ho ho ho.
Ooh! Ooh! There's a song the village kids\nsing about him, too!
The samurai clad in eyes of eight ♪\nHe dug the well, it couldn't wait ♪
But if you find his treasure well ♪\nYou'll see the steaming mouth of hell ♪
Aaand, STOP! Thank you, gentlemen.\nI'll be getting off here.
Well, hello, you two.\nGlad you could make it.
Charming village, isn't it? They're all so\neager to please. A girl doesn't have to\nlift so much as a finger!
Being literally carried around by the locals\nfeels a tad abusive of their goodwill...\nI'm bothered you don't think so, frankly.
In any case... What was it you wished to\nshow us, Mitsuhide?
It's something little Bonnie found out\non a walk while I was taking a nap.\nThere, we're just coming to it now.
Curious, no? Who would travel all this\nway just to draw water?
It does seem rather inconvenient.\nWhat do you make of it?
Uh, hello? Does the buried treasure of\nHinomoto ring a bell? Surely the village\nelder regaled you with the story.
This may just be the well in question.
Wait, you believe in legends now?\nHa ha. That's kind of adorable.
I didn't at first. But have a look\nat the design carved in the well.
I feel like I've seen that octagonal leaf\npattern somewhere before.
I should certainly think so. The eight boar's\neyes are a defining part of my family crest.
Oh. That's pretty cut-and-dry, then.\nSo...what's your house crest doing here?
I've heard a few stories about the old\ntanuki in your family. If he was the\nsamurai in the local tale, it all lines up!
I'm impressed you knew about that.
What's this about a tanuki? I've been doing\nthe pactbound dragon thing for you people\na hundred years now and never heard of it.
That's hardly a surprise, Marishiten.\nMy family makes a point of not talking\nabout him to anyone outside the clan.
He was my ancestor. His name has been\nforgotten. He's called a tanuki, after the\nanimals who love to deceive humans.

This was centuries ago—before my house forged a
soul pact with you. The clan leader entrusted this
tanuki with the family's defense, and he made for
our castle by sea, carrying with him bars of gold
to use as our war chest.
But his ship sank mid-journey, and he vanished\nwithout a trace. When the ship was dredged from\nthe water, the gold was nowhere to be found.

It's hard to believe a chest of heavy gold bars
could have been washed away. What's more, the
circumstances of his ship capsizing were unusual.
One of its crewmen reported seeing the tanuki
hauling the chest just before it went under.
As a result, people began to say that he was driven\nmad by avarice. That the tanuki had stolen the\ngold and sunk the ship on purpose.
The truth of it was never known, though, as\nneither the man nor the treasure was ever\nfound.
But if he was the samurai they spoke of,\ndon't you think it's possible the loot he\ntook is buried here?
The stories do align nicely, but they paint\ntwo vastly different pictures of the man.
Would the savior of a village who toiled for\ntheir benefit be the sort of traitorous villain\nwho would thieve from his own blood?
Sounds like I've piqued your interest, at\nleast. What say we dig up the bottom of\nthis well and see for ourselves?
Could be we find the truth down there.\nSet the record straight.
Marishiten. Send a letter to Sazanka and\nthe others, if you would. Let them know our\nreturn to Hinomoto will be a bit delayed.
Rare to see a paragon of selfless service\nlike you moved by curiosity.
In days past, I would have thought it my\nduty to spend all of my limited time on\nmy lordly duties. Yet now...

Ever since our journey to deliver the
wyrmclan's blessings, I've opened my
eyes to the merits of a slightly more
carefree approach.
Bam. Plan made. Welcome to base\ncamp for our new excavation project.
Let's do this thing, people! A piece of\n(lucrative) Hinomotoan history awaits!
